I think the RSS page just needs to be published (was last published in September)
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/data/bigscreenrss.xml

(will see if we can add a workflow rule so this happens automatically when the form page is saved)

Jamie
Ah, cool, thanks Jamie. I wasn’t certain it actually needed to be published to work. Am sure that’s it, I’ll publish it now.

Hi Finn,

The RSS should now automatically publish when the main data edit page is saved *and* published.

Jamie
Cool, thank you!

Hi,

The crops of some of the locog board members photos aren't amazing.  These are full-sized photos through from Getty.  (see below).  I know the resized versions go into /transform ... but I don't *think* I'm actually allowed in that folder.  How do I get in and edit just the crops?

http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?q=&tag=&start=481&sort=&display=list&age=&related=&scores=&user= 


Thanks!

Liz

Hi Liz,

Oh Dear, they don't look good do they ;-)

I think we may have to tackle this is a more roundabout way, namely letting you manually assign a thumbnail to the photo page, which is it exists is used instead.

* the crops we generate are really internal files and messing with them via the CMS is probably a bad idea.

Jamie

Hm. That would be cool. Would help with related photos as well.

Can you take a look at how much work that would be?

Probably a days work,

We'd need to add a new 'manual thumbnail' field to the image pages and then make sure that version (if it exists) got stored and picked up in search pages instead of the auto generated ones.

Jamie

Or Liz could just go into http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/folder/transform and locate images to reload from there. I guess the danger is that they will get over-written if images get reimported.

e.g. http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/folder/transform/2005700/sc220x120
I'd rather not given them access to that directory for a variety of reasons, I have a billable workaround anyway (in this case) based on letting Liz assign a manual thumbnail to the Photo page.
Probably worth it. Suspect this may keep coming up.

Hi Liz,

There is now an extra thumbnail field in Edit mode, this is only ever used if you need to override the default auto generated one.
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/photos/2009/08/sir-keith-mills-deputy-chair-locog-64804.php

The manually assigned thumbnail will then show up in the Search results / gallery / related views.
http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?q=%22Sir+Keith+Mills%2C+Deputy+Chair+LOCOG%22
http://www.london2012.com/photos/search.php?q=%22Sir+Keith+Mills%2C+Deputy+Chair+LOCOG%22&tag=&start=1&sort=&display=list&age=&related=&scores=&user=

Thumbnails need to be 220x120 (the smaller 90, 63 is generated automatically form the manual thumbnail)

This is now tested and live  

Jamie
Lovely! Works great. Please close ticket.

comments.value:
The change control procedures / stage testing stuff would benefit largely from a Redirects file that can be moved around with no modifications. This could be achieved by removing ALL domain-specifics from the redirect statements and just refer to /urls. According to the apache docs:

"The new URL should be an absolute URL beginning with a scheme and hostname, but a URL-path beginning with a slash may also be used, in which case the scheme and hostname of the current server will be added."

Started looking at a proof of concept on dev.
please update and reassign

I did the mobile redirects in this fashion:

RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{HTTP_USER_AGENT} (nokia|symbian|iphone|blackberry) [NC] 
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} "/(index.php|)$" [NC]
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} "!/mobile" [NC]
RewriteRule (.*) /mobile/ [L]

Note the last line, RewriteRule doesn't have a domain name - hence it redirects to same domain.

I'm fixing this, and the time is being bundled into:
  http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/2105

subject: Making Redirects file domain-agnostic
description:
The change control procedures / stage testing stuff would benefit largely from a Redirects file that can be moved around with no modifications. This could be achieved by removing ALL domain-specifics from the redirect statements and just refer to /urls. According to the apache docs:

"The new URL should be an absolute URL beginning with a scheme and hostname, but a URL-path beginning with a slash may also be used, in which case the scheme and hostname of the current server will be added."

Started looking at a proof of concept on dev.

Hi guys,

I've just had a conversation with the OW team about some changes they would like next year.  At the moment this is a 'wish list' - so I'm looking to you to find out feasibility and price.  Can you please take a look through the attached doc and let me know your thoughts?

Thanks!

Liz

Liz Goulding
Senior New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.twitter.com/london2012

Hi Liz,

Will do..

Jamie
I have a meeting with the OW team on Thursday at noonish.  Could you please get back to me with something before then?
Looks like this is urgent. I think you would like something back from us this morning.
Spoke to Jamie yesterday – but yes, I have a meeting in 39 mins. So vaguely indicative pricing would be Good

Hi,

Just wanted to feed you some information on the latest updates to the OW project.

Best
Zara

Thanks Zara,

Just working up a proposal for the changes we need to make / associated costs.

Taking a bit longer than expected as we want to get the detail right / make sure we can take certain approaches (technically) before we agree to any fixed costs.

Jamie

Thanks, Jamie. Please do have a look at the word doc – there is some more stuff in there which i would suspect is interrelated with the first 3.

The good news is they do have quite a sizable budget which they could be dedicating to this!

Oh good, we spent best part of this morning reminding ourselves how it all worked, thinking up solutions that fell between low cost but a bit of a fudge and those meeting all the OW teams requirements (even ones they probably forgot to ask for, like the image upload working smoothly) and delivering something were proud of.

Just finishing off doc now..
Any further updates on this?  Sorry to press, but they want to launch the registration in early Feb, and I want to make sure that is realistic!

Oh sorry Liz,

Back onto it right now (literally after I stop typing this email)

Jamie
Estimate attached.

Ah - excellent that PO was raised.  Can i please confirm the amount it was for, and that it contained:
1. only the work done for registration
2. include a 10% contingency

Also - did Zara speak to you about the date Roli wants this done by?

Good points. The breakdown of work is as follows:

1. Update events page and Events form - 1 day
2. Update formatting of registration form - 2 days
3. Filter all events by Open Weekend - 2 days
4. Creating an ‘approve’ button - 4 days
5. Send an email on approval - 1 day
6. Amend CVS export - 0.5 days
7. Improvements to image upload - 3 days
8. Refined search update listing (date/time/critics choice) - 2 days
9. Refined search update listing (Postcode) - Not included
10. Category list refinement - 2 days

Total: 17.5 days

Which can be broken down into backend and frontend:

Backend (for Feb 1): 2,3,4,5,6,7,10 - 14.5 days
Frontend (not so urgent): 1,8 - 3 days (plus possible postcode searching)

We didn't add a contingency. We would be happy to do so (but don't want to confuse things if the PO has already been raised).

We are assuming that you want the backend stuff ASAP, i.e. by the end of this month. Please let us know if it's any different.

I think PO has been raised. Will confirm with Roli.

And it’s not so much back/front end (there is front end stuff required for registration ... though confused by dif b/w 1 and 2), but definitely 8 and 9 are less urgent.

Please aim for end of Jan – will get final date from Roli!

Thanks

Looking at Jamie's proposal document, it looks like Item 1 is about changes to the structure of the Events template that is used on the live site while Item 2 is about changing the layout of the registration form, used by organizations submitting events.
Coolio. Thanks

comments.value: It is not immediately obvious by just looking at the page and its metadata.

Hi Zara,

This gets very geeky, very quickly :-) but here goes...

?scores=true (in preview)

If you append ?scores=true to the end of a page in preview you'll see some extra data when you 'view source' 
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/photos/2010/12/ashford-nursery-grows-plants-for-london-2012-garden.php?scores=true

On the page itself (in preview with ?scores=true append) you can also click on a related image and you'll see a popup with similar info.

For example:

<!--tagScore|dateScore(1|2) matches: tag(parklands)  very-recent(20101126)-->

This means that the related image was pulled in because

a) it scored 1 based on the tag (a match, two tags scores 2)
b) it scored 2 based on the date (very recent)

If no tags match then it will revert to most recent.

If more than one tag matches then it /might/ beat date, very recent beats 2 tags, but 2 tags beats a medium aged page (~1 month old) with one tag.

Unlike related content on Sports and Venue pages the related photos on Photo pages are evaluated at publication time, so older pages won't show newer related photo. 

In answer to the inevitable question 'Can we get related photos on Photo pages to work like they do on Sports pages'. The answer is yes, but it would involve a couple of days development and probably another day to test/deploy the code on dev and republish the photos and then to do the same thing on the live server. So ~3 days work in total.

Jamie

Hi Jamie

I don’t really understand this, I’m looking at the pages, but not seeing any extra data.

Can you advise?

Cheers
Zara

Hi Zara,

It's just some extra comment tags, see highlighted line in attached screenshot.

You can also see it if you click on the text of the related image (see second screenshot)

This only works if you append ?scores=true to the url *in preview* (ie. in the CMS)

Lise so..
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/photos/2010/12/ashford-nursery-grows-plants-for-london-2012-garden.php?scores=true

Nb. the earlier https issue is still not resolved, so flow is still a bit broken.

Hi Morag, 

This is now resolved.

Jamie
Thank you – were you able to find out what had happened?

Yes, we added the UK as a default value for BusinessCountry which was fine, but there was also some code that said "if /any/ of the business values is filled in, then check all the other /required/ business fields". In turn because the BusinessCountry now always got set (due to a default value) it meant it the form was also always checking for the business fields even for non-business users.

I'm still not 100% sure where this error crept in, I remember explicitly testing both new and existing registration in both cases, I think when we deployed the version that came with all the other fields closed up when reason=business that we may have only tested the business case.

Really sorry it slipped though, I hope it didn't cause significant issues for you.

The good news it is won't have affected any of the real business signups which I imagine was been the biggest registration drive recently.

* directly un-related, although we noticed still an issue while fixing this bug, is that the Load Balancer isn't maintaining sessions across https connections, the net result of this is that a user may log in and get a session set on one server but then may be sent back to another server without the session cookie and so appear to be logged out. I'll send a separate email with a clearer explanation and raise it with ITS.

Jamie

comments.value:
You know those tickers you get along the bottom of the screen on things like BBC News 24, and Sky Sports News, and general news channels? The ones that just contain scrolling text headlines and nearly always say ‘BREAKING NEWS’ on them?  We have one of those on the London 2012 live site big screens around the UK, and we’ve just been given permission by the BBC to put whatever information we want on them when the live sites are broadcasting London 2012 specific material (which is about 20 minutes every hour).
 
The ticker works by pulling in an RSS feed, and we were going to try and use our latest few news headlines and straplines. But after a few discussions our Comms team in general have decided that they’d like us to set up something a bit more complicated and we were wondering if you guys would be able to build this for us.
 
What we’re looking for is (we imagine) a form with entry fields which we can populate which will generate RSS that the live sites can pull in to populate to ticker.  We were imagining that from our end it would be as simple as a form with, for example, 10 text-only entry boxes. The form would recognise when fields were and weren’t populated and play the populated fields one by one in order, on a loop.
 
So, an example of what we might populate the fields with:
 
Field 1: 20th August 2010 – London 2012 has announced that pole dancing will now be the only Olympic sport
Field 2:
Field 3:
Field 4:
Field 5: 20th August 2010 – Usain Bolt bored of winning everything
Field 6:
Field 7:
Field 8:
Field 9: For all the latest news updates on London 2012 visit www.london2012.com, www.facebook.com/london2012, www.twitter.com/london2012
Field 10:
 
In this example, whenever we updated the form (and clicked a ‘submit’ button, or something?) it would recognise that certain fields were empty, and the RSS the form generated would populate the ticker with the populated fields consecutively. So it would loop 1, 5, and 9, ignoring the rest. We’re thinking we’d update it a lot with all sorts of info to keep things very topical.
 
Does this sound like something you guys could do?
How’s the spec / costing coming for this Jamie?

Hi Finn,

Are you OK with this coming off the retainer, if so I'd expect we'd spend 2 days writing, getting this setup.

What you've written below is fine it terms of a spec for us to work from, so if your OK with us progressing on this with an pretty firm estimate of 2 days then more than happy to progress, we'll prototype something a bit first and we can tweak a bit as we go along and once it's in place within those two days 

Is there any particular RSS format they need (as I said we can tweak this once started, it won't change costs, but would be good to know if there is a preferred version).

Shall we get started?

Jamie

That’s grand Jamie, yep.

Amy who does our video has sent a request to the beeb about what type of RSS they require, have cc:d her here as i’m off until Weds now.

Amy, if you hear from the BBC about this before I get back could you let Jamie know if you get a sec please?
I'm about to start with this - any news from BBC by any chance?

subject: RSS builder
description:
You know those tickers you get along the bottom of the screen on things like BBC News 24, and Sky Sports News, and general news channels? The ones that just contain scrolling text headlines and nearly always say ‘BREAKING NEWS’ on them?  We have one of those on the London 2012 live site big screens around the UK, and we’ve just been given permission by the BBC to put whatever information we want on them when the live sites are broadcasting London 2012 specific material (which is about 20 minutes every hour).
 
The ticker works by pulling in an RSS feed, and we were going to try and use our latest few news headlines and straplines. But after a few discussions our Comms team in general have decided that they’d like us to set up something a bit more complicated and we were wondering if you guys would be able to build this for us.
 
What we’re looking for is (we imagine) a form with entry fields which we can populate which will generate RSS that the live sites can pull in to populate to ticker.  We were imagining that from our end it would be as simple as a form with, for example, 10 text-only entry boxes. The form would recognise when fields were and weren’t populated and play the populated fields one by one in order, on a loop.
 
So, an example of what we might populate the fields with:
 
Field 1: 20th August 2010 – London 2012 has announced that pole dancing will now be the only Olympic sport
Field 2:
Field 3:
Field 4:
Field 5: 20th August 2010 – Usain Bolt bored of winning everything
Field 6:
Field 7:
Field 8:
Field 9: For all the latest news updates on London 2012 visit www.london2012.com, www.facebook.com/london2012, www.twitter.com/london2012
Field 10:
 
In this example, whenever we updated the form (and clicked a ‘submit’ button, or something?) it would recognise that certain fields were empty, and the RSS the form generated would populate the ticker with the populated fields consecutively. So it would loop 1, 5, and 9, ignoring the rest. We’re thinking we’d update it a lot with all sorts of info to keep things very topical.
 
Does this sound like something you guys could do?

comments.value: Specifically, when should we be using 301s (permanent) and when 302s (temporary).
Due date set as Jan 31.

1) Currently:

All redirects created via the short url interface are 301 (Permanent) redirects.
http://www.google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=93633

Google will not penalize you for doing this, but will index / display the URL being pointed to and not the short form URL

We also periodically use 302 temporary redirects when setting up splash pages, ie. replacing the homepage with a splash page. Google normally (they have changed behavior in the past) shows the original page in the SERPS ie. "London 2012 : Home" but displays the Spalsh page "London 2012 : Mascots" when the link is clicked. This is only true for on-domain links ie. both sites / pages are on www.london2012.com

2) Going forward (post SEO development work)

To the outside world (or browsers / bots / spiders) short urls will appear as part of the site and not as redirects. This means that /volunteering to all intents and purposes is the Volunteering hub page. No 301 or 302 Redirects to worry about. It's all done transparently at the webserver/publication level and will appear to the work that that is the sites structure.

We probably want to turn off the old style 301 redirects once we launch the new style SEOpath unless there is a requirement to have multiple paths to a given page (ie. volunteer, volunteering, gamesmaker) in which case we need to keep them as we can only have one official short SEOpath per page (as these will basically become the canonical path for that page).

btw. the above is an answer to a question / clarification, there is no development work to be done here.

subject: SEO: Review of redirects
description: Specifically, when should we be using 301s (permanent) and when 302s (temporary).

comments.value: Page 19: "Adding or removing the .php extension from a URL does not make a difference: the page still loads. Additionally, the URL without .php will load with or without a trailing slash ( / ). Although appearing to be a minor issue, the presence of absence of a trailing slash also denotes a new URL and thus a new page."
Ideally, index pages should all be referenced with a trailing slash.
Due date set as Jan 31.

This ticket / issue is a bit of mix of various issues.

- adding / removing .php
This is a side effect / coincidence of there being a short / redirect url setup with the same path as the url without the .php 
Most pages on the site *do not* work when the .php extension is removed. If a short url is setup in future with the same path as another page without the .php this will still appear to be happening ie. we have a short url called "/diving" and a page called diving.php if we remove the .php it will appear to work but *only* becasue we have a short url which matches the filename without a .php extension.

- Trailing slash ( / )
This will be dealt with as part of the larger SEO url work, all index pages will end in /

- Index pages vs Trailing slash ( / )
This will be dealt with as part of the larger SEO url work, all index pages will end in / rather than index.php
